creator: stuart.miller@orionhealth.com
text:
HTTP Headers configured with a Header Manager and cookies are not sent when
POSTing with the Java HTTP Sampler and using Redirect Automatically. Changing
the request to be a GET ensures the headers and cookies set by previous pages
are sent correctly.

If Redirect Automatically is unchecked and Follow Redirects is checked instead,
the headers and cookies are also sent correctly.

The rest of this description is the request and response headers that show the
cookies and headers aren't being sent (captured with Charles).

Connection: keep-alive
User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 6.0; Windows NT 5.1)
Cookie: JSESSIONID=F51C04C239C5A6C5DB5FD996741D9CBC
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
Content-Length: 461
Host: stuartm.orion.internal:8066
Accept: text/html, image/gif, image/jpeg, *; q=.2, */*; q=.2

HTTP/1.1 302 Moved Temporarily
Date: Mon, 19 Nov 2007 02:27:07 GMT
Server: Apache/2.0.52 (Win32) mod_ssl/2.0.52 OpenSSL/0.9.7e mod_jk/1.2.25
Expires: -1
Cache-Control: no-store
Pragma: no-cache
Location:
http://stuartm.orion.internal:8066/concerto/Context.htm?token=6ccf4faa-28b1-11b2-ad2b-73e237da053e
Content-Language: en-NZ
Content-Length: 0

Host: stuartm.orion.internal:8066

creator: sebb@apache.org
text:
Redirect automatically is not handled by JMeter - it is handled by the HTTP 
protocol implementation.

Not sure that there is anything the JMeter code can do about this, other than 
disallowing auto redirect for POST requests.

In fact this is what HTTP Client does, because redirected POST requests are 
supposed to be subject to user confirmation.
